oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mid-Hudson Scenic Postcards
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photo postcard of Slabsides, taken from the back of the cabin. "SLABSIDES / NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK / BURROUGHS DRIVE / WEST PARK, NEW YORK 12493 / This cabin was built by the poet-naturalist John Burroughs in 1895 and used by him in the last 25 years of his life as a place to study nature at close hand, to write, and to visit with his friends. It is a unique literary shrine, located approx. 1 mile off Route 9W." - letterpress caption from verso of postcard.

This postcard was mailed with a one cent stamp on March 21, 1909; it is post stamped March 22. The hand-written message reads: "Miss Elizabeth Russel; Woodbridge, Conn. ; This is John Burrough's [sic] little log cabin the other side of the river. Quite often girls go over to see him there - I hope you are well. March 21, 1909 Mildred.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Redfield Brothers, Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Old Broadway Sleigh - The Broadway Sleigh represents a period long gone by in New York City, before river tunnels, subways, elevated roads, electric trolleys or horse cars, when winters were more severe than now, when the snow was not removed from the streets, and when the omnibus in summer and sleigh in winter were the common modes of public transportation. - letterpress caption from verso of postcard

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hudson Landing from the Half Moon
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hudson Landing from the "Half Moon" - Henry Hudson, an English navigator in the employ of the Dutch East India Company, while searching for a short passage to China and India, sailed by chance into what is now New York Bay; he started up the river that to-day bears his name on Sept. 2d, 1609, in his ship, "The Half Moon." This voyage ended about where Albany now stands, and in Oct. 4th, he set sail on his return journey to Amsterdam. Hudson was eleven days navigating up the river, a distance that is now traversed as many hours. - letterpress caption from verso of postcard; includes a personal message postmarked New York, N.Y. as well one cent stamp.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Float - Orpheus Before Pluto
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Redfield Brothers, Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Orpheus Before Pluto - Orpheus, the sun of Apollo, played the lyre so well that even the trees and rocks followed him around when he played. His beautiful wife, Eurydice, was bitten by a serpent and died. Orpheus followed her to the regions of the dead, and played so sweetly before Pluto, its king, that he finally consented that Eurydice should go back with him to the land of the living. - letterpress caption from verso of postcard; also contains handwriting.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Float - Arion
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Redfield Brothers, Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Arion - Arion, a famous Corinthian musician was returning home from a musical contest in Sicily, where he had won a great money prize. In order to get his money the sailors plotted to kill him. They gave him time, however, to sing his death song, which so charmed the fishes that when Arion threw himself overboard a dolphin took the musician on his back and brought him safely to his home. This float represents his enthusiastic reception on his arrival. - letterpress captionfrom verso of postcard.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The First Trip of the "Clermont"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Raphael Tuck & Sons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first trip of the "Clermont." The initial trip of the first steamboat, the "Clermont," invented by Robert Fulton, was made on Aug. 11th, 1807. Its destination was Albany, a distance of 150 miles from New York City, and the speed averaged five miles an hour. The fuel was fat pine-wood, which created continuous trail of sparks and smoke. Primitive as it was, it was the progenitor of all steam craft in the world. - letterpress caption from verso of postcard

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Redfield Brothers, Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Clermont - The Clermont was the primitive steamboat in which Robert Fulton made his pioneer voyage on the Hudson River from New York to Albany and Return, starting on Monday, August 17, 1807, and reaching New York again on Friday, August 21. The boat was only about 150 feet long. The round trip fare in those days was $14. - letterpress caption from verso of postcard.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Redfield Brothers, Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first sachem of the Iroquois - The first Sachem of the League was the venerable Atotar-ho, a famous Onondaga chief. He was unapproachable because he was clothed with hissing snakes. - letterpress caption from verso of postcard.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Henry Hudson Memorial Bridge to be erected
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Raphael Tuck & Sons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Henry Hudson Memorial Bridge. To commemorate the 300th anniversary of Henry Hudson's first trip up the river that bears his name, a memorial bridge is to be erected at Spuyten Duyvil , New York, crossing the Harlem River. It will be of re-enforced concrete, 2870 feet long, 80 feet wide and 270 feet high (above tide water), with a central span on 725 feet. The upper story is to have a roadway 50 feet wide and two walks for pedestrians, having a width of 15 feet each; four rapid transit tracks will be laid on the lower story. The bridge will cost about $4,000,000 and require nearly four years to build. - letterpress caption from verso of postcard. Reverse also a personal message, a NY postage and a one cent stamp.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Robert Fulton
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Raphael Tuck & Sons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Robert Fulton, the pioneer of steam navigation, was born in Fulton, Lancaster Co., Pa., Nov. 14th 1765. The "Clermont" , designed by him, was the first steamboat to make a successful trip. She was 133 feet long, 18 feet wide, 9 feet deep and 160 tons measurement. Fulton died in New York City on Feb. 24th, 1815, and is buried in the Trinity Churchyard, where in 1901, a granite monument with a bronze medallion was erected by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. - letterpress caption from verso of postcard

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dock landing of the "Clermont"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Raphael Tuck & Sons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dock landing of the "Clermont." The "Clermont," the first boat propelled by steam, required 32 hours to go to Albany from New York City-about 150 miles. The fare was $7., and freight was carried at the rate of three cents a pound. Plying the same route on the Hudson to-day are palatial steamboats, more than three times the size, carrying 2000 passengers, and making, the trip easily in ten hours. - letterpress caption from verso of postcard.
